A. Pagaltzis wrote:

> Considering that you were only just fervently talking about how
> database people tend to see tables everywhere, it surprises me
> that you go on to say to XML should be your hammer and every
> problem a nail.

Funny. I thought I was quite careful to say the opposite. XML most 
deifnitely doesn;t do everything, but what it can't do (with a couple of 
interesting if esoteric exceptions) JSON can't do either.

I remain unimpressed by the claims people make that JSON is easier. I've 
worked with both, and it doesn't seem so to me. JSON may be easier than 
DOM, but it is not easier than XML.

The claims of JSON's superiority seem mostly based on confusing XML with 
DOM on the one hand, while refusing to learn what XML actually is. 
Developers like to be able to just shove JSON into JavaScript and not 
leanr anything new. Of course, evaling JSON as JavaScript doesn't 
actually work, but most developers haven't noticed that yet.

-- 
Elliotte Rusty Harold  elharo@...
